situation.title: Traveling to/from Great Britain and Northern Ireland from December 20, 2020 onwards
situation.meta_description: Povinnosti osob, které cestují z/do Velké Británie a Severního Irska.

content.processed:
All persons, who have entered the Czech Republic after 3:30 pm on December 20, 2020, and stayed at least 12 hours in Great Britain or Northern Ireland within past 14 days, are obliged:

  • to fill in the Public Health Passenger Locator Form
  • to isolate themselves at home. The isolation has to last either 10 days or until a PCR test carried out at least 5 days after entering the Czech Republic turns a negative result. The test result must be presented to the passenger’s nearest regional public health office.

This measure aims to improve the safety of the citizens. It is an extraordinary measure imposed due to a new high contagious mutation of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which has lately emerged in the UK. It is necessary to react quickly in order to stop the spread and protect the citizens.

Please be extremely considerate during the quarantine. You may leave the place you are quarantining yourself if you need to get basic needs (buying groceries, caring for your children or pets, using financial & postal services etc.). Please, however, avoid times when shops, offices, etc. are full of people and adhere strictly to the “3Z rule”.

From 00:00am January 1, 2021, direct flights from Great Britain and Northern Ireland heading for any airport in the Czech Republic are allowed again. This applies until further notice. Solely for ambulance, evacuation, life-saving flights and flights, at which all passengers are able to prove that their RT-PCR or antigene test carried out in the UK not longer than 72 hours before departure has turned a negative result.

Furthermore, each passenger of such a flight has either

  a) to be a citizen of the Czech Republic with his/her place of residence therein (or his/her accompanying family member),

b) to be a citizen of any other EU member state with a valid second residence permit for the Czech Republic issued (or his/her accompanying family member), or

c) to be a holder of a valid long-term visa or long-term/permanent residence permit for the Czech Republic.

A foreigner, for whom the statements in a) to c) do not apply, is allowed to use such a flight to reach his/her connecting flight, provided the connecting flight departs within not longer than 12 hours after landing and from the same airport.

Passengers have as well to fulfil other conditions for entering the Czech Republic. For an overview of those, please see the Travelling abroad section.

Please be careful, as it is not yet known to which extent exactly the novel SARS-CoV-2 mutation is more contagious (first analysis shows 70%). You may spread the virus even if you don’t show any symptoms of the disease.

Furthermore, all those who arrived in the Czech Republic from December 10, 2020 to December 20, 2020 at 3:30 pm and who resided in the last 14 days in the Great Britain and Northern Ireland are required to fill in the Public Health Passenger Locator Form before entering the Czech Republic and undergo the RT-PCR test no later than 5 days after return. If they have failed to do so, the Regional Hygiene Station (public health office) will order quarantine measures for them.
